Award.AwardTitle: NEESR: Novel Embedded Diagnostics Wireless Structural Monitoring Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Structural health monitoring has been the intense focus of research in structural engineering with significant advances made over the past decade in the development of wireless monitoring sensing systems. When empowered with data interrogation algorithms, such systems can provide critical damage assessment information to first responders immediately after an extreme event and can greatly facilitate the recovery process. This research investigates a new methodology for post-event structural damage assessment, using wireless sensors, through the following tasks: (a) design a novel direct residual displacement sensing unit, (b) develop new and identify existing damage algorithms suitable for embedding in sensing nodes, (c) embed the damage detection algorithms on the microprocessor of the sensing nodes, (d) calibrate the algorithms with available data from previous laboratory or numerical experiments, and (e) verify their predictive capabilities though three payload experiments on projects using the George E. Brown, Jr. Network for Earthquake Engineering Simulation (NEES) facilities and Japan's E-Defense shake table. The payload experiments will use the multi-story reinforced concrete frame to be tested at the E-Defense shake table facility in Miki, Japan, the full scale unibody light wood-frame structure test to be conducted at the NEES shake table facility at the University of California, San Diego, and the unbounded post-tensioned rocking wall test to be conducted at the NEES shake table facility at the University of Nevada, Reno. Each of these three types of structural systems has unique characteristics with their specific challenges. Data from this research will be archived and made available to the public through the NEES Project Warehouse/data repository (http://www.nees.org).

A new advanced method for direct measurement of residual displacement, with confirmation of such measurements through the payload experiments, can represent a major breakthrough in the ability to monitor and assess structural performance after a major event in near real time, thus providing critical information to first responders and owners in a timely manner. Demonstration of embedding of complex damage detection algorithms and verification of the functionality of these algorithms through the three payload experiments will greatly enhance the ability to deploy wireless sensors more effectively in the field. This award is part of the National Earthquake Hazards Reduction Program (NEHRP).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objectives of this project were to:

  1. Participate in three NEES tests and one E-Defense test by installing our wireless sensors to collect data in parallel with other data systems.
  2. Design and develop new wireless sensor for direct displacement measurements
  3. Test the new sensor at the Blume Center laboratory with small-scale specimens to provide initial verification.
  4. Conduct further verification of the new sensor through participation in one or more of the NEES
  5. Develop a more extensive wireless network communications protocol and test the protocol in variety of noisy environments.
  6. Develop algorithms that utilize acceleration measurements and subsequently the direct displacement sensors for rapid damage assessment due to extreme events such as a large earthquake.

 

Objective 1: Two test at NEES Tests at the University of Nevada, Reno (UNT) included a rocking wall experiment ( PREcast Wall with End Columns) conducted by Professor S. Sriratnam, Iowa State University and a non-structural components performance an RC frame conducted by Professor Maragakis (UNR). A third test was the two-story wood frame conducted by Professors Miranda and Deierlein at the University of California, San Diego.

 

The team collaborated with the National University of Taiwan's Center for Research in Earthquake Engineering (NCREE) (Professor C.H. Loh). The tests were on three story steel frame structures shaken to gradually increasing earthquake motions. The new wireless 3D accelerometers with 3D gyroscope sensors were used and new algorithms were developed.

 

Two icing experiments were conducted at the Denmark Technical University (DTU) using our wireless sensor network on a bridge cable. The data were applied to various algorithms to identify ice mass formation and accretion.

 

Objective 2: A new wireless sensor system was designed deploying 3D accelerometers, 3D gyroscopes, temperature and humidity sensors. The system is named SnowFort: http://web.stanford.edu/group/snowfort/

 

Objective 3: The new sensors were tested at the John. A. Blume Earthquake Engineering Center shaking table facility to calibrate, verify functionality and reliability.

 

Objective 4: In all cases the sensors performed as expected and data were collected for further analyses.

 

Objective 5: Challenges encountered at some of the test facilities due to heavy equipment and presence of extensive electromagnetic fields were overcome and permanent solutions were developed.

 

Objective 6: Previously developed algorithms and several new algorithms include:

  • Extension of the rotation algorithm to develop specific parameters for wide range of applications.
  • Development of a new wavelet-based algorithm for damage detection including estimation of false positive and false negative. The reliability of the algorithm was 97%.
  • Development of sequential damage detection and localization algorithm to identify damage occurrence time and most likely location.
  • Development of new rotation algorithm utilizing the accelerometer and gyroscope measurements to estimate the residual and dynamic displacements. Excellent agreement obtained with direct measurements by LVDTs.
  • Two ice detection and ice-mass correlation algorithms were developed showing to be better predictors than the Fourier transform based methods.

E-Defense in Japan did not conduct their experiment.

 

The major contributions and achievements of the project are:

 

  • The combination of accelerometer and gyroscope measurement provide excellent estimates of residual and dynamic displacements. Such displacement measurements are essential for rapid damage assessment immediately after an earthquake and provide information to first responders as to the safety of a structure to be entered. It can provide alerts to occupants of critical damage or impending collapse.
  • The SnowFort system has significantly improved wireless communication capabilities over other existing systems. In addition, it is the firs sensing system that incorporates 3D gyroscopes as an integral part of the sensing nodes making it more versatile for wide range of applications. The system reliability was tested under several extreme conditions including environments with heavy electromagnetic fields and icing conditions.
  • The damage detection and localization algorithms represent significant improvement in structural health monitoring capabilities over previously developed models.
  • In all laboratory tests that the research team participated the sensing system performed very well - further proof of the reliability of the system.
  • Two conference papers presenting results from the research of this project received "Best Student Paper Awards".

Two students received their Ph.D. degrees with support form this grant. A third student conducted research as a Master's Degree candidate. One female student worked on the project. All three students participated in two or more experiments working with the sensor nodes and network. With the addition of the subcontract to UT, El Paso and one young female faculty, Assistant Professor Guyrong Yan, was given the opportunity to conduct research in this field. The PI serves as her mentor under the ENHANCE project also supported by NSF.

As a result of the research from this project, 14 journal or juried conference papers have been or are submitted for publication. In addition, research results have been presented at numerous conferences, seminars, keynote lectures and invited papers.

 


Last Modified: 08/08/2017
Modified by: Anne S Kiremidjian
